text: With Obama, it was the SOTU calling out of the SCOTUS decision in Citizens United. With Trump, it is his fairly frequent calling out of various federal judges, though the Curiel example is the first one that everyone remembers. That stuff isn't OK.
author: LizMair

text: I would also argue that both Obama and Trump engaged in attacks on the judiciary that, while not unconstitutional per se, certainly seem inconsistent with an acceptance of the notion of checks and balances and division of power as established in the Constitution.
author: LizMair

text: ...for the day Sessions bailed. That was a total undermining of the constitutional imperative to nominate and for the Senate to advise and consent. Fortunately, it has now been stopped since Barr was nominated and confirmed and is in office.
author: LizMair

text: And I'll give you a third for free: Trump keeping "acting AG" Whitaker around for as long as he did rather than nominating an AG. He had been planning to ditch Sessions for literally months. In the circumstances, there was no excuse for not having an AG nominee teed up...
author: LizMair

text: 2) Here's another: His "emergency declaration" which, like Obama with DACA/DAPA, was a vast exceeding of executive authority that neither should get/should have gotten away with. Obama said he couldn't do it unilaterally, then did. Trump said he didn't need to do it, but did.
author: LizMair

text:
I'll give you 2 examples right off the bat:

1) Strikes on Syria without cong authorization and specifically a declaration of war (something Congress has been increasingly willing to dispense with over time, but the Trump example-- and I'd argue Obama's w Libya-- were egregious).
author: LizMair

text: My 2 cents here: Trump has done damage to constitutional norms. The problem is, he did it after others did it. His is perhaps worse, but it's part of a long-running trend in a bad direction. This makes it hard for some people to see it and blame him for it.
author: LizMair

text: Honestly didn't track the debate that closely. But a) wasn't that a local, not US Chamber, issue? Local and national chambers function VERY differently and b) the very wealthy, if they're eating in DC, are doing it for business and it's a business expense so they could care less.
author: LizMair

text: Obviously, even if you're employing someone here unlawfully, you're SUPPOSED to follow rules re: wages and labor conditions. It's just that unlawful immigrants have exactly no standing to argue for employers obeying those laws.
author: LizMair

text: The Chamber perhaps argues against its members' own interests on immigration, but the reality is, if we did amnesty for all 11 or 12 million, employers couldn't get away with paying them less than minimum wage and engaging in similar unlawful actions.

text: "Mair," "Major," "Mayor" and "Mair" all come from "meilleur"-- all denotations of higher status but not actual nobility. Of course, somewhere along the way, our specific family became pretty working class and on the lower end of the socio-economic spectrum.
author: LizMair

text: Only people in Scotland know I'm Scottish-- but the French are almost right, since "Mair" does come from the same root word as "Maire"-- "meilleur," i.e., better than you, because we were at one time when French was more widely used civil servants.
author: LizMair

text: Everyone thinks "Mair" is "Meyer." Interestingly, people in the US and Germany think this. People in Spain think I'm Spanish, though, because there is a last name "Mair." And people in France suspect my family is somehow French because "Mair" looks like "Maire."
author: LizMair

text: ... then either proceed with normal labor or induce and if baby comes out alive, do whatever you can medically to keep it alive. Don’t leave it at someone else’s discretion to give it pain meds but otherwise just leave it to die. That’s fucking inhumane. It just is.
author: LizMair

text: It is also, of course, worth noting that  there are lots of instances where doctors figure out once a kid is born that they’re wrong about a disabled kid’s ability to survive. It would seem the answer is, if you’re in 2nd/3rd trimester, get as close to due date as possible...
author: LizMair

text: Anyway, I don’t think most of these late-term abortion advocates think it’s OK for a woman in my position to induce early unless at 35 weeks you’re already carrying a 10 pounder. But they think abortion the day before the due date is OK. In short, they’re a mess.
author: LizMair

text: As it happens, I was lucky and my kid kicked me hard and broke my water at 35 weeks anyway so out he came. He was 20 inches and 7 pounds 8 ounces. If he’d stayed in until induction was technically permitted (week 39) he would have been enormous— gaining more than a pound a week.
author: LizMair

text: It’d be really nice if people buying into this argument would also buy into the argument that a woman who’s carrying a kid who’s already over 7lbs at 35 weeks, as mine was, can schedule an induction for week 36. Yet no one countenances that. And it’s telling.
author: LizMair

text: If you have an “abortion” the day before you’re due, it’s no different to... giving birth. And if you’re doing it because your baby is doomed to die within minutes anyway, does going 24 hours early somehow help? Clearly not.
author: LizMair

text: These parents are conned out of sometimes tens of thousands of dollars, without realizing that what they’re buying into basically cannot work, by definition. It’s just fraud. That’s it.
author: LizMair

text: It’s worth remembering that parents who are desperate for a “solution” to their kid’s homosexuality are victims here, too. They’re being preyed on by snake oil salesmen. We don’t allow that when it comes to other obviously fraudulent products/services and this is no different.
author: LizMair

text: It is speech, but so are sales pitches made by those selling Ponzi schemes. And conversion therapy, like those, are basically fraud. I wouldn’t ban conversion therapy outright but I would ban it for patients under 18.

text: If you're someone who genuinely believes unlawful immigration and/or immigrants are a problem, you should be asking why support the Trump administration at all. And "they're trying" shouldn't be the answer, because THEY ARE NOT.
author: LizMair

text: Bottom line is, this administration has had 2 yrs to address what they perceive as a massive problem with unlawful immigration. Almost all of this is within the purview of the executive. Congress plays a small role. They've failed by their own standards.
author: LizMair

text: And by the way, when workers come here on those visas, their employers are responsible for their housing, health care, etc., so this is one way we ensure immigrants aren't relying on public dollars AT ALL.
author: LizMair

text: Are we increasing the number of, say, H2 visas so that those among this group who are actually MIGRANTS can apply in their home countries, get vetted, and come here to work in an orderly fashion? Because Texas homebuilders and ag need the workers.

text: Are we building facilities-- not tent cities-- equipped to intake families, as opposed to single men? Unclear.

text: Maybe that's a reflection on her stances on Trump during 2016. But I think it was also a perception that women under deliver because, hey, look at the map! Where we've run women they don't seem to win as much. It works for Dems but not for us. Which is a BS conclusion, but exists
author: LizMair

text: Part of that may have been that Wagner just really, honestly didn't want to run in this tough cycle and deal with the Trump stuff. But I will be honest, I also heard a lot of people pooh-pooh her chances like "oh, Missouri voters will never go for her."
author: LizMair

text: Yes, that's harder. But it is where some perceptions of "women can't win" on the part of certain consultants tend to result in fewer women being recruited in the first place. E.g., I'm totally find with Josh Harder (I think he'll be great). But no one got Ann Wagner in that race!
author: LizMair

text: And then, when they lose, punditocracy engages in the "GOP is a party of white men" and internally, you get the occasional consultant who is just convinced women can't win because, hey, you expected Carly Fiorina and Meg Whitman to beat a 10-point registration differential in CA.
author: LizMair

text: I'm not saying women SHOULDN'T run in hard districts. In particular, if that's where you live and you want to serve, then you should run there recognizing you'll probably lose. But the party tends to engage in a weird reverse sexism: Men can't win tough fights so find girls.
author: LizMair

text: Blackburn is a rare example of where we ran a woman in a tricky-ish to hold seat, and she actually did hold it. But people were worried. Why do you think Trump was in there doing rallies for her before election day? Because her race wasn't sewn up.
author: LizMair

text: Another example: Karen Handel. Clearly knows how to win elections (she's won statewide for God's sake). But hey, run her in a district that's not a special election versus a not-totally-flawed person, and boom, she's gone.
author: LizMair

text: Comstock is another example. Extremely hardworking candidate. And I don't think there's a single thing she could have done to win re-election this year, other than (maybe) switch parties which is kind of not the point in this discussion.
author: LizMair

text: Some of our best candidates this cycle? Young Kim in Orange County. Busted her ass-- hard. Possibly one of the hardest workers I've ever heard of in politics. But running in a district where odds always were she'd lose.
author: LizMair

text: I know this as someone who has been asked to run for Congress myself in two different districts. They're both very, very tough.
author: LizMair

text: One thing the GOP could do to address this is start running more women in SAFE seats when there's an opening. Don't just promote women for the tough-to-win/hold districts and states. We really do have a tendency to do the latter.

text: 3) On which subject, it's worth pointing out the fundamental interpretation problem that I think existed with regard to this tweet. I AM BRITISH. British people are sarcastic. I'm married to a British immigrant (OMG) and British people think it's funny...

author: LizMair

text: Good news: Despite having had to scream at one @DollarCars employee who said they “don’t care about social media” (direct quote) and having had to scream at her manager too, $75 fee was refunded as was cost of the tiny drop of gas needed to bring tank full. @thriftycars
author: LizMair

text: Suffice to say I am fucking livid about this. Bonus points: We’re dealing with all this with my mother, who has a back and hip problem, and my 4 year-old in tow. @thriftycars @DollarCars
author: LizMair

text: .@thriftycars @DollarCars I want my $75 back. I also want the cost of any fuel used to get to the airport when we refueled by the cruise terminal refunded. And frankly, I’d like a credit towards a future rental. This is a massive fuckup. I just hope we don’t miss our cruise!
author: LizMair

text: 4) So, we go to return the car to the @thriftycars “location” we are referred to by Thrifty’s staff. Guess what? It doesn’t exist either. So we have to drive back to the airport to return and then get an Uber to the cruise terminal. And we were charged $75 for this “privilege.”
author: LizMair

text: 3) now I go to return to @dollarcars which does not in fact have a return center at the cruise terminal— only at some hotel 3 miles away. 2 out of 3 staff I spoke to didn’t even know the @dollarcars “location” at the cruise terminal didn’t exist.
author: LizMair

text: 1) I pre-booked, when I booked the car, to return it to the cruise terminal 2) I paid $75 for the privilege 3) when I arrived in Honolulu— right on schedule @thriftycars was shut so they had me go to @dollarcars— they’re the same company.
author: LizMair

author: LizMair

text: 7) I have every confidence that the talented writers @weeklystandard will find new, great homes. But let's not all buy into the narrative that this was some super-stealth effort for the @dcexaminer to poach new readers by the back door by shuttering a fellow investee.
author: LizMair

text: 6) It's a sad reflection on the media business as a whole, but if ANY organization has ANY fat that can be trimmed and they don't do it, or ANY way to add revenue (short of legit selling out, which some pubs-- not @weeklystandard or @dcexaminer-- have done), they won't last.
author: LizMair

text: 5) The @weeklystandard has some extremely talented writers on staff and I hope they find new homes. Candidly, I wouldn't be surprised if some land at @dcexaminer. But media is a very tough business to be in, and you've got to eke out every dollar.
author: LizMair

text: 4) But I think bottom line, the perception that @dcexaminer kneecapped the @weeklystandard that is being put out there through some emotional and injudicious comments, is just inaccurate. And I don't think, having regard to staffing at @dcexaminer that this is so much about Trump
author: LizMair

text: 3) With all that said, I think the @weeklystandard should be allowed to go find a buyer, or raise the money through GoFundMe or something itself to buy the publication out from current ownership and give it a fresh chance of survival.
author: LizMair

text: 2) I still think the "the Examiner is Trumpy" argument is being overplayed and is ridiculous. I DO think the Examiner has made significant investments in building out its reporting staff and I bet there are traffic differentials the owners are seeing from that.
author: LizMair

text: That is even more relevant where the owner of a business has plowed more and more money into it over the years without seeing the ROI they expected. You don't want to add to your losses if there is any conceivable way of mitigating against that.
author: LizMair

text: ...you always want to offer people who ALREADY PAID YOU MONEY an alternative having already paid you money. I would bet a decent amount that this isn't about trying to turn @weeklystandard fanatics into @dcexaminer fanatics; it's about trying to keep from having to refund huge $.
author: LizMair

text: I'm just saying, Rubio's timing is a little off and I think before he runs for President again (which I'm sure he will), he needs to work on that slightly. Either that or just be who he really is instead of trying to be 25% someone else. Let the chips fall where they may.
author: LizMair

text: I don't care especially, I still like Rubio because unlike the overwhelming majority of voters, I do vote on policy and he's generally pretty good on policy in my view. And if he ran for President again, there's a strong chance I'd vote for him again in a primary (I did in 16).
author: LizMair

text: Getting "Trumpy"-- which candidate should regard as a behavioral mandate not a policy one-- is what Rubio probably should have done if he wanted to stake out that ground in 2016. Now, he's a little late to that party, IMO.
author: LizMair

text: Now we have the GOP having sustained losses in a midterm that were predictable, but were also worse than needed bc, frankly, Trump isn't popular and voters don't vote on policy (i.e., Trumpism), they vote on personality. But Rubio veers towards Trumpism.
author: LizMair

text: The reason was, GOP voters were shopping for a candidate who would throw lots of punches, and ideally ones to the gut that hit other candidates hard. It was engaging, cathartic blood sport. Rubio got there a little late, tho.
author: LizMair

text: Example: In 2016, Rubio cottoned on late to the fact that the GOP electorate was super pissed off and wanted an asshole who wasn't going to play nice or clean to rep them that year. There's a reason he got the attention he did with the "small hands" stuff.
author: LizMair

text: Example: in 2008, he was all in with the most big government social conservative in the field, Mike Huckabee. But big government conservatism had already crested under Bush and was being viewed skeptically by a lot of different GOP voters.
author: LizMair

text: I like Rubio and have donated to him, but the thing to know here is that he tends to be a little behind rather than ahead of the curve in adapting to political trends. That's one reason why he hasn't performed as strongly as he could in various contexts.
author: LizMair

author: LizMair

text: I agree with you insofar as I think the EU has probably been useful in depriving Germany of an opportunity to re-arm and get back to its tricks from the Franco-Prussian War, WWI and WWII. But that's an EU failing, not the EU provoking something.
author: LizMair

text: I think that is true to a degree in the UK. I think in Germany and Italy, especially, but some other EU countries, there have been centuries-old long-running problems with nationalism that would exist no matter what. But EU "democratic deficits" provide a convenient excuse.

text: But the generalized French view is very much that the EU contained a Germany that constantly got belligerent and aggressive whenever nationalism spiked. And I can see their point. It's just that I'm not... French.

text: Solved or put on temporary hiatus? I'm not in favor of the EU because I see it as a bulwark against German nationalist aggression (I have other reasons I like it, like I like customs unions and quicker immigration processes).
